hypotheses: Hypothesis 1a: Bilingual students will, on average, have higher scores in English as a foreign language compared to the monolingual group.
Hypothesis 1b: Bilingual students with relatively stronger skills in the language of instruction will have an advantage over monolinguals.
claim.statement: The study investigates the effect of immigrant bilingualism on learning English as a foreign language, controlling for confounding background variables and examining the effect of proficiency in the instructional language at school.

data.source: Assessment of Reading and Mathematics Development Study (ELEMENT)
data.notes: Data were collected from a representative sample of students from a major European city.

method.description: The study analyzed the effect of bilingualism on English language learning by examining a sample of German 6th graders, controlling for cognitive abilities, age, gender, socio-economic status, parental education, and cultural capital.
steps: Conduct regression analyses to assess English achievement among groups.
Control for background characteristics in analyses.
method.control_variables: General cognitive abilities, age, gender, socio-economic status, parental education, cultural capital

results.summary: The study found that immigrant bilingualism can have significant advantages for learning English as a foreign language, particularly when controlling for background factors. Proficiency in the instructional language was a major determinant of English language outcomes.

metadata.original_paper_title: The effect of speaking a minority language at home on foreign language learning
